question: How many fielders can be outside the 30-yard circle during powerplay overs?
answer: A maximum of two (2) fielders can be outside the thirty (30) yard circle in the first six (6) overs.

question: What is the maximum number of fast short-pitched deliveries allowed per over?
answer: A bowler shall be limited to one (1) fast short-pitched delivery per over.

question: How many fielders can be on the leg side at any point of time?
answer: Only five (5) fielders can field on the leg side at any point of time.

question: What happens if a bowler delivers more than one fast short-pitched ball in an over?
answer: The umpire at the bowler's end shall call and signal no ball on each occasion. The umpire shall call and signal 'no ball' and then tap the head with the other hand.

question: How long does an incoming batsman have to take guard after a wicket falls?
answer: The incoming batsman must be in position to take guard or for his partner to be ready to receive the next ball within one-minute-thirty seconds (1m 30s) of the fall of the previous wicket.

question: Can a substitute player bat, bowl, or act as captain?
answer: No, substitutes may only field for the injured player. A substitute may not bat, bowl, wicket-keep or act as captain.

question: What is the penalty for bowling a wide ball?
answer: A penalty of one (1) run for a wide shall be scored. This penalty shall stand in addition to any other runs, which are scored or awarded.

question: How many fielders can be behind square leg during delivery?
answer: At the instant of the bowler's delivery there shall not be more than two (2) fielders, other than the wicket-keeper, behind the popping crease on the on side, commonly referred to as being 'behind square leg'.

question: What constitutes a dangerous high full-pitched ball for slow bowling?
answer: A slow delivery, which passes or would have passed on the full above shoulder height of the striker standing upright at the crease, is to be deemed dangerous and unfair.

question: What is the time limit for bowling the first ball of the final over?
answer: All sides are expected to bowl the first (1st) ball of the last of their twenty (20) overs within one-hour-twenty-five (1h 25min) playing time.

question: How many fielders can be outside the 30-yard circle after powerplay overs?
answer: For the remaining fourteen (14) overs not more than five (5) players can be outside the thirty (30) yard circle.

question: What penalty is imposed for time wasting by the fielding side?
answer: If there is any further wasting by the fielding side in that innings, the umpire shall award five (5) penalty runs to the batting side.

question: Can a runner be provided for an injured batsman?
answer: No, a runner for a batsman when batting is not permitted under any circumstances.

question: What happens if a team fails to bowl within the over-rate time limit?
answer: If the bowling team fails to bowl the first ball of the final over of their innings within the stipulated time, they will lose one fielder from outside of the 30-yard circle for the remainder of the innings.

question: How is net run rate calculated when a team is bowled out?
answer: In the event of a team being all out in less than its full quota of overs, the calculation of its net run rate shall be based on the full quota of overs to which it would have been entitled and not on the number of overs in which the team was dismissed.

question: What is the penalty for unfair movement by fielders during bowling?
answer: Any unfair movement by the fielding team in the field while the bowler is running in to bowl, would lead to the imposition of a five-run penalty on the fielding team and the delivery would be deemed a 'Dead Ball'.

question: How long is the warm-up period allowed before a match?
answer: Prior to the match, teams are entitled to a five (5) minute warm-up period.

question: When can coaching be provided to players during a match?
answer: Coaching can be provided to the player(s) during the two (2) two minute (2) interval breaks at seven (7) and fourteen (14) overs and during the twenty (20) minute interval break between innings.

question: What happens after a bowler's second warning for dangerous bowling?
answer: Should there be any further instance by the same bowler in that innings, the umpire shall call and signal no ball and when the ball is dead direct the captain to take the bowler off forthwith. The bowler thus taken off shall not be allowed to bowl again in that innings.

question: What constitutes a dangerous high full-pitched ball for fast bowling?
answer: Any delivery other than a slow paced one, which passes or would have passed on the full above waist height of the striker standing upright at the crease is deemed dangerous and unfair.

question: What is the timed out rule for incoming batsmen?
answer: If the incoming batsman is not in position to take guard or his partner is not ready to receive the next ball within two (2) minutes of the fall of the previous wicket, the action should be regarded as time wasting.

question: What types of warm-up are prohibited on the pitch?
answer: There shall be no warm-up of any kind, at any time, on the pitch or on either of the two (2) strips parallel and immediately adjacent to the pitch.

question: What is the six-run penalty in over-rate penalties related to?
answer: The six (6) run penalty for each over not bowled will apply - all sides are expected to bowl the first ball of the last of their twenty overs within one-hour-twenty-five playing time.

question: How many interval breaks are allowed during an innings for coaching?
answer: There are two (2) two minute (2) interval breaks at seven (7) and fourteen (14) overs during which coaching can be provided.

question: What happens if there's further time wasting by batsmen after a warning?
answer: If there is any further time wasting by any batsman in that innings, the umpire shall award five (5) penalty runs to the fielding side.
